							&lt;div class="category"&gt;
				    					           				               &lt;span class="red"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.geek.com/category/news/"&gt;News&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;
										&lt;span&gt;
						By &lt;span class="by"&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.geek.com/author/Matthew-2/" title="Posts by Matthew Humphries" rel="author"&gt;Matthew Humphries&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt; 
						Jan. 5, 2015 10:58 am					&lt;/span&gt;
									&lt;/div&gt;
									&lt;figure&gt;
											 
						&lt;img width="590" height="330" src="http://www.geek.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/X24_01-590x330.jpg" class="attachment-post-thumbnail wp-post-image" alt="X24_01" /&gt;						
											&lt;/figure&gt;
																		
				&lt;article&gt;
					&lt;p&gt;Lenovo is announcing a number of new or updated products ahead of CES tomorrow, including a new range of ThinkPad laptops and the novel ThinkPad Stack. But the thing that caught my eye is the ThinkVision X24 monitor due to just how minimal it is.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.geek.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/X24_04.jpg"&gt;&lt;img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1612747" src="http://www.geek.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/X24_04-590x330.jpg" alt="X24_04" width="590" height="330" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The X24 is a 24-inch monitor using a 23.8-inch panel. In terms of the image this display produces, it&#8217;s pretty standard. Lenovo has &lt;a href="http://news.lenovo.com/images/20034/Lenovo%20ThinkVision%20X24%20Spec%20Sheet.pdf" target="_blank"&gt;used an IPS panel&lt;/a&gt; with a Full HD resolution of 1920 x 1080, brightness is rated at 250ns, and response time is 7ms. It has a contrast ratio of 1000:1, dynamic contrast of 3 million:1, and viewing angles of 178 degrees both horizontally and vertically. A standard desktop display, right? Then you see what this monitor looks like.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.geek.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/X24_02.jpg"&gt;&lt;img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1612745" src="http://www.geek.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/X24_02-590x330.jpg" alt="X24_02" width="590" height="330" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.geek.com/tag/lenovo/"&gt;Lenovo&lt;/a&gt; has used a New-Blade IPS panel which uses a &lt;a href="http://www.slashgear.com/lenovo-thinkvision-x24-full-hd-display-loses-the-border-04361750/" target="_blank"&gt;pre-coated metal surface&lt;/a&gt; instead of the more typical plastic casing you see on most monitors. The end result is a display that Lenovo classes as borderless. It still has a border around the screen edge, but it&#8217;s very thin. The metal coating also keeps the display very thin. It&#8217;s only 7.5mm thick, but gets thicker at the bottom to allow for the tilting stand to be attached and the ports to be made accessible.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/uyLLY2Fp6Tk?rel=0?wmode=transparent" width="590" height="332" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The look is of a premium monitor which only requires a tiny stand. You only get DisplayPort and HDMI inputs, but for the look and the price tag of $249 I doubt many people will complain. And if you like to have more than one display hooked up to your PC the X24 looks like a good choice because of the lack of border allowing multiple displays to sit closer together.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href="http://www.geek.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/X24_03.jpg"&gt;&lt;img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1612746" src="http://www.geek.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/X24_03-590x330.jpg" alt="X24_03" width="590" height="330" /&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;You&#8217;ll be able to purchase the ThinkVision X24 from April this year. Tempted?&lt;/p&gt;
